required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Time Limited Eating in Type 1 Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: Time Limited Eating in New-Onset Type 1 Diabetes: Feasibility, Acceptability, and Effect on Beta-cell Function

brief_summary.textblock: This study is a randomized-control pilot study that aims to evaluate Time Limited Eating (TLE) in the pediatric T1D population, implemented within the first six months after diagnosis. This period is characterized by residual β-cell function, during which TLE may have the ability to preserve and improve β-cell activity, indicated by increased C-peptide production. The investigators aim to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and safety of TLE in the pediatric T1D population, as well as to investigate the impact of TLE on β-cell function, insulin sensitivity, and glycemic control.

detailed_description.textblock:
This will be a two-armed study with an intervention and control group. Feasibility and acceptability will be assessed by using questionnaires. Safety will be indicated by hypoglycemia occurrence. β-cell function and insulin sensitivity will be evaluated using mixed meal tolerance test with C-peptide and glucose levels. Glycemic control will be indicated by continuous glucose monitor (CGM). Block randomization will be utilized to ensure the groups are balanced in terms of ethnicity and BMI. The study period will be 13 weeks in duration, including a week-long run-in period and a 12 week intervention period. There will be two in-person study visits at week 0 and week 13. Anthropometrics including weight, height, and pubertal status will be evaluated at these times.
Group 1- Standard Care (control)
- includes a minimum 12-hour feeding window
- no caloric restriction will be used
- will wear a continuous glucose monitor
Group 2 - TLE (intervention)
- includes an 8-hour feed/16-hour fast for 7 days per week
- will be instructed to consume all of their calories from 11 AM to 7 PM
- can consume non-caloric beverages (water, tea, coffee) during the fasting period
- will wear a continuous glucose monitor
- no caloric restriction will be used

primary_outcome.measure: Acceptability and feasibility of intervention, as indicated by the "Intervention Satisfaction Survey"
primary_outcome.description: Likert scale "Agree strongly" is 1, "Agree" is 2, "Neutral" is 3, "Disagree" is 4, and "Disagree strongly" is 5. Lower scores indicate more satisfaction, higher scores indicate low satisfaction.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in beta-cell function at 12 weeks, as indicated by mixed meal tolerance test with C-peptide levels
primary_outcome.description: C-peptide and glucose levels will be performed at baseline and 60-, 90-, and 120-minutes post-meal. Baseline plasma C-peptide concentration divided by the baseline plasma glucose concentration will be calculated as a pragmatic marker of β-cell function. The area under the stimulated C-peptide curve will then be calculated, which will be the primary outcome examined.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in glycemic control at 12 weeks, as indicated by continuous glucose monitoring (percent time in range), and HbA1c
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 12 weeks; HbA1c: Baseline and 12 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Continuous glucose monitors will be worn for duration of the study, glycemic control will be evaluated using percent time in range. HbA1c will reflect glycemic control over time.
Hypoglycemia will be defined as blood sugar < 70 mg/dL on continuous glucose monitor. Frequency and severity of hypoglycemia will be used to assess safety of intervention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Dietary patterns, as indicated by Nutrient Data System Recall (NDSR)
secondary_outcome.description: 24-hour dietary recall, 55 questions, ~40 minutes to complete.

secondary_outcome.measure: Quality of life, as indicated by Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory
secondary_outcome.description: Likert scale "Never" is 0, "Almost Never" is 1, "Sometimes" is 2, "Often" is 3, and "Almost Always" is 4

secondary_outcome.measure: Stress level, as indicated by Perceived Stress Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Likert scale "Never" is 0, "Almost Never" is 1, "Sometimes" is 2, "Fairly Often" is 3, and "Very Often" is 4

secondary_outcome.measure: Physical activity frequency, as indicated by Physical Activity Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: Likert scale "No days" is 0, "1 day" is 1, "2-3 days" is 2, "4-5 days" is 3, and "6-7 days" is 4

secondary_outcome.measure: Binge Eating, as indicated by Binge Eating Disorder Screener
secondary_outcome.description: Likert scale "Never or rarely" is 0, "Sometimes" is 1, "Often" is 2, "Always" is 3. Additionally, two yes or no questions.

arm_group.description: includes a minimum 12-hour feeding window no caloric restriction will be used will wear a continuous glucose monitor

includes an 8-hour feed/16-hour fast for 7 days per week will be instructed to consume all of their calories from 11 AM to 7 PM can consume non-caloric beverages (water, tea, coffee) during the fasting period will wear a continuous glucose monitor no caloric restriction will be used

intervention.description: Includes an 8-hour feed/16-hour fast for 7 days per week, with consumption of all of calories from 11 AM to 7 PM. Can consume non-caloric beverages (water, tea, coffee) during the fasting period. No caloric restriction will be used.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- includes age of 12-25 years
- T1D diagnosed within 6 months
- at least one positive pancreatic antibody including glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) antibody, islet tyrosine phosphatase 2 (IA2) antibody, or insulin antibody
- can be on either insulin injections or insulin pump
- can be of any BMI status
- can speak any language
Exclusion Criteria:
- negative pancreatic antibodies
- unwillingness to wear a CGM
